original.name: Alliance
original.body: Place one of your ships from one of your colonies on this card and give it to another player. For the rest of the game, the two of you have an alliance. When either of you is the main player in an encounter, he or she must always invite their ally.

revised.name: Alliance
revised.body: The offense places one ship from any of their colonies onto this card and give it to another player. For the rest of the game, those players alliance. When either are a main player in an encounter, they must always invite their ally.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited for wording consistency.


Revisions from The Praw

Edited to remove an ambigious use of the 'you' pronoun.

original.name: Black Hole
original.body: During this encounter, ships that would be lost to the warp are instead removed from the game entirely. A player cannot have fewer ships left in the game than the number of foreign colonies required to win. Any ships lost that would reduce a player below this number are sent to the warp after all.

revised.name: Black Hole
revised.body: During this encounter, ships that would be lost to the warp are instead removed from the game. A player cannot have fewer ships left in the game than the number of foreign colonies required to win. Any ships lost that would reduce a player below this number are sent to the warp as usual.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited for wording consistency.

original.name: The Cosmic Guardian
original.body:
While the Cosmic Guardian is in play, all attack cards higher than 20 are considered to be negotiate cards.

Discard the Entropy Beast and the Witness when the Cosmic Guardian enters play.

revised.name: The Cosmic Guardian
revised.body:
While The Cosmic Guardian is in play, all attack cards higher than 20 are considered to be negotiate cards.

Discard The Entropy Beast and The Witness when The Cosmic Guardian enters play.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited for capitalization

homebrew.name: The Cosmic Guardian
homebrew.body: All attack cards higher than 20 are considered to be negotiate cards.
homebrew.revisionNotes:
House rule from The Praw

Edited to change this hazard to a semi-permanet hazard, which gives a much cleaner hazard that interacts intuitively with Cosmic Odyssey hazards.

original.name: Cosmic Nebula
original.body: During this encounter, any alien powers that are used are immediately zapped.

original.name: Cosmic Upheaval
original.body: Immediately shuffle all players' hands together and then deal each player back as many cards as he or she had beforehand. No cards may be played in response to this card.

revised.name: Cosmic Upheaval
revised.body: Immediately shuffle all players' hands together and then deal each player back as many cards as they had beforehand. No cards may be played in response to this card.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from The Praw

Edited to include gender-neutral language.

original.name: Energy Fields
original.body: Each main player draws two cards, showing them to the other players, before allies are invited.

revised.name: Energy Fields
revised.body: Before allies are invited, each main player draws two cards from the deck, showing them to all players.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited to clarify that the card draws came from the cosmic deck, to eliminate the ambiguity of whether "the other players" means the non-main players or all players, and to remove redundancy.


Revisions from The Praw

Edited to making the timing clearer when hazard is drawn in destiny.

original.name: The Entropy Beast
original.body:
While the Entropy Beast is in play, each time a special or wild destiny card is drawn, remove the planet with the most ships on it from the game (offense breaks ties), sending all ships on it to the warp. If a player's home system is reduced below three planets, all players lose the game.

Discard the Cosmic Guardian and the Witness when the Entropy Beast enters play.

revised.name: The Entropy Beast
revised.body:
While The Entropy Beast is in play, each time a special or wild destiny card is drawn, remove the planet with the most ships on it from the game (offense breaks ties), sending all ships on it to the warp. If a player's home system is reduced below three planets, all players lose the game.

Discard The Cosmic Guardian and The Witness when The Entropy Beast enters play.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited for capitalization

homebrew.name: The Entropy Beast
homebrew.body: Each time a special or wild destiny card is drawn, remove the planet with the most ships on it from the game (offense breaks ties), sending all ships on it to the warp. If a player's home system is reduced below three planets, all players lose the game.
homebrew.revisionNotes:
House rule from The Praw

Edited to change this hazard to a semi-permanet hazard, which gives a much cleaner hazard that interacts intuitively with Cosmic Odyssey hazards.

original.name: Galactic Council
original.body: Instead of having a normal encounter, all of the players in the game have three minutes to make a deal. All players must accept the deal or it fails. If the deal fails, all players lose 3 ships to the warp.

revised.name: Galactic Council
revised.body: Instead of having a normal encounter, proceed to the reveal phase. All of the players in the game have three minutes to make a deal. All players must accept the deal or it fails. If the deal fails, all players lose 3 ships to the warp.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited to clarify that the encounter skips ahead to the reveal phase.

original.name: It's Full of Stars...
original.body: During this encounter, allies may send ships from the warp into the encounter (normal max applies). If the ships survive the encounter, they do not return to the warp.

revised.name: It's Full of Stars...
revised.body: During this encounter, allies may retrieve ships from the warp to send into the encounter (the normal limit of four applies).
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited to properly use the game term "retrieve" (for consistency with Super Observer and clarity with effects that trigger on ship retrieval), to strike its overclarifying final sentence (to avoid any rules-lawyering against effects that send winning ships to the warp), and to eliminate sloppy "max" shorthand.

original.name: Meteor Storm
original.body: During this encounter, if both main players reveal attack cards, add together the totals of both sides. If the combined total is over 25, a deadly meteor storm is triggered by the fighting, causing both sides to lose, regardless of other game effects.

original.name: Mirror Universe
original.body: Immediately flip over both the discard pile and the deck. The deck becomes the new discard pile and vice versa. Afterwards, shuffle the new deck.

original.name: Odd Way to Win a War
original.body: During this encounter, if one main player reveals an odd-numbered attack card and the other reveals an even-numbered attack card, the player who revealed the odd-numbered attack card automatically wins the encounter.

original.name: Psychic Switcheroo
original.body: For the duration of this encounter, the two main players trade powers. This includes everything that goes with a power, such as the Miser's hoard, Industrialist's stack, etc. After the end of the encounter, the main players trade back.

revised.name: Psychic Switcheroo
revised.body: After the defense has been determined, the two main players trade powers. This includes everything that goes with a power, such as the Miser's hoard, the Industrialist's stack, etc. After the end of the encounter, powers traded due to this hazard are given back.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited for wording consistency.


Revisions from The Praw

Edited to clarify what happens when the hazard is drawn in destiny and the defense has not yet been determined, and to prevent erroneous trading of powers at the end of the encounter if the main players change (e.g. via Delegator)

original.name: Reverse Rewards
original.body: Defensive allies receive a colony if their side wins this encounter, while offensive allies receive defender rewards if their side wins this encounter.

revised.name: Reverse Rewards
revised.body: Defensive allies receive a colony if their side wins this encounter, while offensive allies receive rewards if their side wins this encounter.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited to fix the rewards bug.

original.name: Sargasso Web
original.body: During this encounter, any cards played (including encounter cards, flares, artifacts, etc.) are removed from the game after taking effect.

original.name: Temporal Anomaly
original.body: Play now proceeds in the opposite direction (i.e., if play was passing clockwise, it now proceeds counterclockwise).

original.name: The Witness
original.body:
While The Witness is in play, players do not lose their alien powers because they have too few home colonies. Any player who has lost his or her alien power in this manner gets it back while The Witness remains in play.

Discard The Entropy Beast and The Cosmic Guardian when The Witness enters play.

revised.name: The Witness
revised.body:
While The Witness is in play, players do not lose their alien powers because of having too few home colonies. Any player who has lost his or her alien power in this manner gets it back while The Witness remains in play.

Discard The Entropy Beast and The Cosmic Guardian when The Witness enters play.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from the Cosmodex

Edited for capitalization and wording consistency.

homebrew.name: The Witness
homebrew.body: Players do not lose their alien powers because of having too few home colonies. Any player who has lost their alien power in this manner gets it back while this is in play.
homebrew.revisionNotes:
House rule from The Praw

Edited to change this hazard to a semi-permanet hazard, which gives a much cleaner hazard that interacts intuitively with Cosmic Odyssey hazards.

original.name: Learn from the Past
original.body: If you have fewer than eight cards in your hand, choose and draw cards from the discard pile until you have eight cards, if possible. The encounter immediately ends successfully.
original.body2: If you have fewer than eight cards in your hand, you may draw a random card from the discard pile.

original.name: New Recruits
original.body: Free all of your ships from the warp and place them on your home colonies. The encounter immediately ends successfully.
original.body2: Free one of your ships from the warp and place it on one of your home colonies.

original.name: Peace Dividend
original.body: Gain two rewards for each planet you occupy with another player. The encounter immediately ends successfully.
original.body2: If you occupy at least one planet with the offense, gain two rewards.

original.name: Re-Armament
original.body: You may discard any number of cards from your hand. Then, draw cards until you have eight cards in hane. The encounter immediately ends successfully.
original.body2: If you have fewer than eight cards in hand, you may draw one card.

original.name: Strip Mining
original.body: For each ship you have on a foreign colony, draw one card. The encounter immediately ends successfully.
original.body2: If you occupy a planet with the offense, draw one card.

original.name: Universe Merge
original.body: Draw a random unused alien sheet and place it faceup in front of you. If it has Game Setup text or is not allowed in this game, discard it and draw again. You have this alien's power in addition to your own. The encounter immediately ends successfully.
original.body2: Draw two flares from the unused flare deck.

original.name: Confined Launches
original.body: Each player that sends ships into this encounter can only send ships from one planet in their home system. If the offense has no ships on home planets, the offense immediately loses the encounter.

original.name: Domestic Difficulties
original.body: Each ally that sends ships into this encounter can only send ships from their foreign colonies. Players that have no foreign colonies cannot become allies.

original.name: Economic Aid
original.body: The offense gives one card of their choice from their hand to each player whose system they have a colony in. If the offense would not have enough cards to do this, they send one of their ships from each of their foreign colonies to the warp instead.

original.name: Ill-Gotten Gains
original.body:
Add the Reward Deck variant (🕮10). If it was already being used, add the Ultra Reward Deck sub-variant. If the Ultra Reward Deck sub-variant was already being used, starting with the offense and proceeding clockwise, each player draws one card from the reward deck.

Then, if there are at least three cards in the hazard deck, suffle this card into it.

original.name: Incentives
original.body: The defense looks at the top six cards of the deck and sets them aside facedown. If the defense wins, they may draw any number of the cards, give any number to their allies, and discard the rest. If the offense wins, they may look at the set-aside cards, draw any number of them, and discard the rest. Otherwise, discard the set-aside cards.

revised.name: Incentives
revised.body: Before allies are invited, the defense looks at the top six cards of the deck and sets them aside facedown. If the defense wins, they may draw any number of the cards, give any number to their allies, and discard the rest. If the offense wins, they may look at the set-aside cards, draw any number of them, and discard the rest. Otherwise, discard the set-aside cards.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from The Praw

Edited to clarify the timing when the hazard is drawn in destiny (before allies are invited was chosen as the timing simple because "after the defense is determined, the defense..." was clunky to read and say aloud.

original.name: No Quarter
original.body: During the planning phase, each main player cannot select a negotiate card if they could select an attack card. If one main player reveals a negotiate card and the other reveals an attack card, no compensation is collected.

original.name: Obligatory Solidarity
original.body: If a main player loses this encounter, the player to their left must send a number of their ships to the warp from any of their colonies equal to the number of ships that that main player had lost in the encounter.

revised.name: Obligatory Solidarity
revised.body: If a main player loses this encounter, the player to their left must send a number of their ships to the warp from any of their colonies equal to the number of ships the losing main player had lost in the encounter.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from The Praw

Edited for clarity.

original.name: Psionic Resonator
original.body:
During this encounter, this card may be offered as part of a deal. Otherwise, at the end of the encounter, it is added to the winner's hand (after compensation, if any). While this card is in a player's hand, it has the following ability:

After you reveal an attack card, you may reveal this card to treat the attack card at an attack 15 or, if you discard this card, an attack 30.

original.name: Shameful War
original.body: At the end of this encounter, for each revealed attack card or played reinforcement card, its owner must discard one card from their hand at random, if able. Then, each player who revealed a negotiate card gains one reward, and each non-main player who is not an ally gains two rewards.

revised.name: Shameful War
revised.body: At the end of this encounter, for each revealed attack card or played reinforcement card, its owner must discard one card from their hand at random, if able. Then, each player who revealed a negotiate card recieves one reward, and each non-main player who is not an ally recieves two rewards.
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from The Praw

Edited for wording consistency.

original.name: Supply Mix-Up
original.body: The offense discards their hand (this effect does not end the encounter). Each other player gives a card of their choice from their hand. Then, each player draws one card from the deck.

original.name: Tech Advantage
original.body: If a main player wins this encounter, they draw a tech card (even if the technology variant [🕮9] is not being used). If there is a successful deal, each main player draws a tech card.

original.name: Unstable
original.body: After determining the winner of the encounter, add both encounter total together. If the sum is at least 42, the planet explodes and is removed from the game. All ships in the encounter are sent to the warp.

original.name: Warp Research
original.body: If the offense wins this encounter, they may release all of their ships from the warp. If the defense wins, all players except the offense may free all of their ships from the warp.

original.name: Win, Lose, or Draw
original.body: For each ship the offense has in the encounter: if the offense wins they draw one card from the deck; if they lose they give the defense one card from their hand at random; or if they attempt to make a deal, the players have an additional 30 seconds.

original.name: Danger Zone
original.body:
Add the Extremely Hazardous sub-variant (🕮11).

When this card is discarded, remove that sub-variant.

original.name: Easy Does It
original.body:
Add the Procedural Change sub-variant (🕮11).

When this card is discarded, remove that sub-variant.

original.name: Enforceable Cease Fire
original.body: After revealing encounter cards, if only one main player reveals an attack card, their side immediately loses the encounter, regardless of other game effects.

original.name: Real Estate Swindle
original.body: After a deal has been made that includes establishing a colony, each player in that deal may discard a negotiate card from their hand to cancel one colony that would be established. If this results in no colonies being established or nothing else happening in the deal, the deal is unsuccessful

revised.name: Real Estate Swindle
revised.body: After a deal has been made that includes establishing a colony, each player in that deal may discard a negotiate card from their hand to cancel one colony that would be established. If this results in no colonies being established and nothing else happening in the deal, the deal is unsuccessful
revised.revisionNotes:
Revisions from The Praw

Edited to make the last sentence more in line with the original intention.

original.name: Re-Reinforcement
original.body: The value of each played reinforcement card is doubled.

original.name: Subspace Interference
original.body:
If there are only three players in the game, discard this card (without discarding a previous semi-permament hazard, if any). Then, draw another hazard card.

Main players cannot invite more than one player to ally.
